requirements:
Basic To-Do List Website Requirements
User Interface:

Simple input field to add new tasks quickly.

List display area showing tasks clearly.

Checkboxes or toggles to mark tasks as completed.

Edit and delete options for existing tasks.

Responsive design for use on both desktop and mobile devices.

Task Management:

Ability to add, edit, and delete tasks.

Mark tasks as complete or incomplete.

Option to prioritize or categorize tasks.

Save tasks persistently (local storage or backend database).

User Experience:

Clear visual differentiation between completed and pending tasks.

Easy navigation and intuitive controls.

Option to reorder tasks by drag and drop or priority.

Technical Requirements:

Responsive front-end using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Optional backend for user authentication and task storage (using database).

Cross-browser compatibility.

Performance optimized for fast load and smooth interactions.

functional_requirements.description: Users can add new tasks to their to-do list.
acceptance_criteria: When a user types a task into the input field and presses 'Enter' or clicks an 'Add' button, the new task appears in the task list.
The input field is cleared after a task is added.

functional_requirements.description: Display all current tasks in a list format.
acceptance_criteria: All added tasks are displayed in a clear, scrollable list.
Each task in the list shows its description.

functional_requirements.description: Users can mark a task as completed or not completed.
acceptance_criteria: Each task has a checkbox or a similar control.
Clicking the checkbox toggles the task's status between 'pending' and 'completed'.
Completed tasks are visually distinct from pending tasks (e.g., strikethrough text, different color).

functional_requirements.description: Users can remove a task from the list.
acceptance_criteria: Clicking the 'Delete' button permanently removes the task from the list.
A confirmation prompt can be shown before deletion to prevent accidental removal.

functional_requirements.description: Users can edit the description of an existing task.
acceptance_criteria: Clicking the 'Edit' button makes the task text editable in-place.
Saving the edited text updates the task in the list.

functional_requirements.description: Tasks are saved persistently in the user's browser using Local Storage.
acceptance_criteria: Tasks remain in the list after the browser is closed and reopened.

functional_requirements.description: Allow users to reorder tasks to manage priorities.
acceptance_criteria: Users can drag and drop tasks to change their order in the list.
The new order is saved persistently.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application must be responsive and work seamlessly on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.
metrics: All interactive elements are easily clickable on touch screens.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should load quickly and interactions (adding, deleting, editing tasks) should feel instantaneous.
metrics: Initial page load time under 2 seconds on a standard 3G connection.
UI updates in under 100ms after user interaction.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application must function correctly on the latest versions of major web browsers.
metrics: Full functionality on the latest two versions of Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should be usable by people with disabilities.
metrics: Semantic HTML and ARIA attributes are used correctly.

risks: Data Loss: Since data is stored in local storage, users can lose all their tasks if they clear their browser data. This should be communicated to the user.
Scope Creep: The project could grow to include features like user accounts, cloud sync, and collaboration, which would significantly increase complexity and require a backend.
Browser Incompatibility: Minor differences in JavaScript or CSS implementation across browsers could lead to inconsistent behavior or appearance.
assumptions: The initial version will use browser local storage for persistence. User authentication and multi-user collaboration are out of scope.
The application does not require backend and database infrastructure for the initial release.
The design will be simple, clean, and functional, without the need for complex custom graphics or animations.
